Dispute_Type: Human rights complaint regarding employment discrimination
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission erred in dismissing the complaint under s. 41(1)(c) of the CHRA
Evidence_Assessment: Commission failed to adequately consider Mr. Hicks's arguments on family status and disability
Burden_of_Proof: On complainant to establish prima facie discrimination
Legal_Rule: Under s. 41(1)(c) of the CHRA, the Commission must not deal with a complaint if it is beyond its jurisdiction; s. 3(1) prohibits discrimination based on family status and disability; ss. 7 and 10 prohibit discriminatory practices in employment
Procedural_Issue: Failure to properly consider relevant jurisprudence and arguments
Grounds_for_Claim: Discrimination based on family status and disability
Decision_Maker: Canadian Human Rights Commission (initial), Federal Court (on judicial review)
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Commission’s decision found unreasonable due to lack of consideration of applicant's arguments
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of TDRA Directive, impact on Mr. Hicks, link to family status and disability
Legal_Framework: Canadian Human Rights Act, including ss. 3(1), 7, 10, and 41(1)(c)
Applicant_Challenge: Commission applied too narrow an interpretation of 'family status' and ignored established jurisprudence
Court_Result: Judicial review allowed; complaint remitted to a new decision-maker for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, legal arguments, policy interpretation
Remedy_Requested: Reconsideration of the human rights complaint
Remedy_Sought: Quashing of Commission's decision and referral back for new assessment
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review followed by administrative reconsideration
Legal_Provision: s. 41(1)(c), s. 3(1), ss. 7 and 10 of the CHRA
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: s. 41(1)(c), s. 3(1), ss. 7 and 10 of the CHRA
Applicable_Process: Human rights complaint process under CHRA, followed by judicial review
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction under the Canadian Human Rights Act
Governing_Rule: s. 41(1)(c) CHRA – jurisdictional bar to complaints
